awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Colloidal Quantum Dot Image Sensors for Low-Cost Short-Wave Infrared Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a low-cost infrared imaging device that enables real-time monitoring of agricultural products for crop management and product quality inspection. Handheld and drone-mountable spectroscopic tools are gaining traction, but their limited spectral range fails to directly measure the unique identifiers of crop maturity and quality such as oil and sugar contents. Furthermore, this innovation, as a platform technology, will address a broader need of the infrared community for lower cost detector arrays and enable system integrators to develop camera systems to increase the safety of driver-assisted vehicles, improve the reliability of advanced manufacturing techniques, and enhance national security.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project develops a photodetector array produced using infrared-tunable semiconductor nanocrystals, or colloidal quantum dots. Unlike crystalline semiconductor technologies, these colloidal quantum dot inks are fashioned into photodetector devices directly on the electronic circuits using inexpensive solution coating techniques, which enables the development of a small pixel pitch focal plane array with a spectral range from 1000-2500 nm and pixel resolution greater than 640x512 to address market opportunities in low-cost imaging systems. The Phase I project objective is to develop a colloidal quantum dot detector array that competes on performance with existing technologies for shortwave infrared sensing and is compatible with vacuum packaging techniques by controlling the impact of engineering factors such as surface chemistry, reagent concentration, and process temperature on the performance and thermal stability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
QDIR has completed its National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project. The objectives of this effort included establishing a manner of integrating patent-pending mercury telluride (HgTe) colloidal quantum dot (CQD) photodetectors with commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) readout integrated circuits (ROICs) and enhancing thermal stability of these materials for semiconductor packaging.

The technical challenges addressed during this Phase I effort included:

(1)   HgTe CQDs degrade at relatively low temperatures that limit their operational use in the field and make them incompatible with standard semiconductor hermetic packaging processes.

(2)   HgTe CQD photodetectors in the extended shortwave infrared spectrum have not been demonstrated or evaluated on a 2D focal plane array for imaging. HgTe CQD photodetector compatibility with silicon readout integrated circuits has not been addressed or a manner of producing such a device developed.

As a result of this NSF sponsored work, QDIR achieved key milestones to de-risk the technology toward commercialization that include significantly improved thermal stability of HgTe CQD thin films from 80oC up to 160oC while preserving optical and electrical properties and demonstrating preliminary active imaging with a 1280?720 resolution, 8-microns pitch HgTe CQD focal plane array with detection up to 2500 nm wavelength light. This outcome of this work advances the HgTe CQD focal plane array to a technology readiness level (TRL) 4?that is, component validation in a laboratory environment. Subsequent efforts that expand on this NSF work will seek to fully integrate thermally stable HgTe CQD photodetectors with COTS ROICs, establish packaging compatibility, and evaluate sensor reliability when subjected to environment conditions.

The potential value to the customer created from this work is a significant cost reduction for extended shortwave infrared focal plane arrays on an HD sensor format, enabling the next generation of high-resolution and high-volume solutions for defense and commercial end users. The commercially available II-VI and III-V semiconductor materials for infrared sensing are prohibitively expensive for these markets. The commercialization of a cost-effective high-resolution infrared sensor has potential impact for such applications as national security, monitoring crop health for precision agriculture, non-destructive evaluation of food and drug products, professional surveillance, and the safety of driver-assisted systems and autonomous navigation in low-visibility environments.
